questions.text: A road traffic accident has occurred, and the first response team has arrived at the scene. Which of the following is not a key priority in prehospital care?
questions.correct_answer: D. Transport immediately and delay interventions

questions.text: After a high-speed road traffic accident, a trauma team arrives to find multiple critically injured patients. According to the trimodal mortality model, which statement is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate deaths occur days after the injury

options.label: B
options.text: Early deaths occur within hours of reaching the hospital

options.label: C
options.text: Majority of deaths are due to cardiac causes

options.label: D
options.text: Late deaths are mostly due to internal hemorrhage

questions.correct_answer: B. Early deaths occur within hours of reaching the hospital
questions.explanation:
Immediate death

Early death

Late death
  • This peak occurs seconds to minutes after the injury. (Option A)
  • Due to the extreme nature of these injuries, very few patients in this category can be saved, and prevention remains the most effective way to address this peak.
  • This peak occurs within minutes to several hours post-injury.
  • The "golden hour" of trauma care, characterized by a need for rapid assessment and resuscitation, is crucial in managing these patients.
  • This peak emerges days to weeks after the initial injury.
  • Severe and nonsurvivable injury
  • Irreversible brain injury
  • Hemorrhages of organs like:
  • Heart
  • Aorta
  • Liver
  • Lungs
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Intracranial hemorrhage/ brain lacerations/ contusions
  • Hemorrhage of respiratory or abdominal organs.
  • Multiple small injuries causing major blood loss.
  • Infection/sepsis or Multiorgan failure (MODS) (80% cases) (Option D)
  • Brain injury
  • Hemorrhage

questions.text: After a major earthquake, a patient presents with a compound fracture and spinal injuries. Considering the severity of these injuries and the urgency of treatment, which triage color code is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Colour

Priority

Medical Need

Clinical Status

Examples

Red (Option B)

 

First

Immediate

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment given early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural haematomas

Yellow (Option D)

Second

Urgent

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment given within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries

Green (Option C)

Third

Non-Urgent

Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations

Black (Option A)

Last

Unsalvageable

Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/ loss of chest or abdominal wall structures

questions.text: In an emergency situation in the casualty, the ATLS protocol is followed after a patient who was in a road traffic accident is brought to the hospital. Which of the following is not a component in the primary evaluation of the patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Detailed history of the patient

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient arrives at the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The ED physician is assessing whether to order spinal imaging. Which of the following findings does not indicate that spinal imaging is necessary?
A critically injured patient is brought to the emergency department. The primary assessment is started. In the following algorithm identify the missing step (a) and action (b).

options.label: A
options.text: a- Assess airway, b- Establish stable airway

options.label: B
options.text: a- Assess circulation, b- Prevent shock

options.label: C
options.text: a- Establish airway, b- Assess circulation

options.label: D
options.text: a- Assess airway, b- Assess circulation

questions.correct_answer: A. a- Assess airway, b- Establish stable airway

questions.text: A road accident patient, stabilized with no severe external injuries, suddenly develops tachycardia, weak pulses, hypotension, and tachypnoea. Which ATLS primary assessment component is most likely causing these symptoms?

A 35-year-old male is brought in after a fall from height and is found to be in hypovolemic shock. According to ATLS protocol, which of the following investigations is not recommended during the primary survey to identify the cause of the life-threatening bleed?
Which of the following statements is true regarding the CRASH-2 trial in trauma? (TXA= Tranexamic acid)

options.label: A
options.text: TXA is more effective when given after 3 hours of trauma.

options.label: B
options.text: TXA reduced all-cause mortality versus placebo.

options.label: C
options.text: TXA in children worsens pulmonary and neurological outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: CRASH-2 showed TXA is ineffective in trauma.

questions.correct_answer: B. TXA reduced all-cause mortality versus placebo.

questions.text: During the primary survey of a trauma patient in the emergency department, which of the following injuries is not classified as life-threatening under the category of “breathing” problems?

A 45-year-old man is found unconscious after a fall from a ladder. In the emergency department, his eyes do not open even in response to pain; he is making incomprehensible sounds, and he exhibits abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.explanation:
Category

Response

Score

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

To speech

3

To pain

2

None

1

Verbal Response (V)

Oriented

5

Confused conversation

4

Inappropriate words

3

Incomprehensible sounds

2

None

1

Motor Response (M)

Obeys commands

6

Localizes to pain

5

Withdraws from pain

4

Abnormal flexion (decorticate)

3

Abnormal extension (decerebrate)

2

No response

1

Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification

Minor head injury

GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness)

Mild head injury

GCS 14 or 15 with LOC

Moderate head injury

GCS 9 - 13

Severe head injury

GCS 3 - 8

Pupils Unreactive to Light

Pupil Reactivity Score

Both Pupils

2

One Pupil

1

Neither Pupil

0

questions.text: A 25-year-old male involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident is brought to the emergency department. After completing the primary survey and stabilizing the patient, the trauma team begins the secondary survey. Which of the following steps is not a part of the secondary survey?
questions.explanation:
Primary Survey: Focuses on immediate life-saving interventions.

Secondary Survey: Conducted after the patient is stabilized.

Airway with cervical spine protection

Complete head-to-toe physical examination

Breathing and ventilation

Full neurological examination (e.g., GCS)

Circulation with hemorrhage control

History taking using the AMPLE mnemonic

Disability (neurological status)

Examination for fractures, soft tissue injuries

Exposure and environmental control (e.g., prevent hypothermia)

Detailed examination of all systems

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with mid-facial trauma from a car accident is stabilized and the secondary survey begins. Which of the following is not an appropriate step in the secondary survey?

options.label: B
options.text: Digital rectal examination for spinal injury

options.label: C
options.text: Nasogastric tube in a patient with mid-facial fractures

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat FAST examination for abdominal injury

questions.correct_answer: C. Nasogastric tube in a patient with mid-facial fractures
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Prerequisites
  • Primary survey must be completed.
  • Resuscitation initiated.
  • All life-threatening conditions identified and addressed.
  • Normalization of vital signs should have begun.

Obtain AMPLE History

(Option A)

A focused history covering: Allergies, Medications, Previous medical history/illness or Pregnancy, Last meal, Events/environment related to the injury. This guides ongoing care and anticipates complications.

Complete Physical Examination
  • Systematic head-to-toe exam including front, back, sides, and hidden areas (scalp, axillae, perineum).
  • Reassess airway and lung function.

Vital Signs Assessment
  • Monitor vital signs regularly.
  • Narrow pulse pressure and tachycardia suggest hypovolemic shock.
  • Be cautious with delayed hemodynamic changes in the elderly.

Head and Face Examination

(Option C)
  • Check for scalp hematomas, skull depression, facial fractures, septal hematomas, raccoon eyes, or Battle’s sign.
  • Avoid nasogastric tube insertion if facial trauma is present.

Neck Examination
  • Immobilize and palpate the neck.
  • Rule out cervical spine injury with imaging or clinical criteria..

Chest Examination
  • Palpate for tenderness, crepitus, and fractures.
  • Inspect for seatbelt bruising and assess respiratory and heart sounds.

Abdomen Examination
  • Look for distension, bruising, tenderness, and marks.
  • Assess for peritoneal injury.

Pelvic and Rectal Examination

(Option B)
  • Check for pelvic instability and perineal injury.
  • Perform digital rectal exam if there is suspicion of rectal or urethral injury, especially in spinal cord injury, pelvic fractures or gunshot wounds to the pelvis.

Genital Examination
  • Vaginal examination in women with pelvic fractures or lacerations.
  • Assess for signs of vaginal trauma or pregnancy-related complications.

Extremities Examination

Evaluate for fractures, tenderness, deformities, neurovascular status, and signs of compartment syndrome.

Neurological Examination
  • Reassess Glasgow Coma Scale
  • Evaluate sensory and motor functions, pupillary response, and signs of head injury.

FAST

(Option D)

Use Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma (FAST) to check for internal bleeding in abdominal injury or unexplained blood loss.

Special Considerations
  • Update tetanus status.
  • Assess urine output.
  • Remove dressings to reassess injuries.
  • Remove cervical collar briefly to evaluate the neck while maintaining immobilization.

Diagnostic Tests and Consultations

Obtain additional imaging or lab tests as needed and request specialist consultations.

Tertiary Survey

Conducted within 24 hours for multisystem trauma patients to identify missed injuries from primary and secondary surveys.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision with unstable vitals and multiple injuries. Which trauma severity score is most appropriate for predicting his likelihood of survival?
questions.correct_answer: C. Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS)
questions.explanation:
Score

Key Parameters

Application

ISS

Anatomical injury in body regions (AIS system)

Measures overall injury severity

RTS

GCS, Respiratory Rate, Systolic BP

Physiological response to trauma

TRISS

Combination of ISS, RTS, and Age

Predicts survival probability in trauma

MESS

Limb ischemia, shock, age, and energy of injury

Predicts need for amputation in limb trauma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is admitted to the hospital after a major traumatic injury. On the third day post-trauma, his oxygen consumption and metabolic rate have increased significantly, and he exhibits elevated catecholamine levels. Which phase of the metabolic response is this patient most likely in?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Timing

Key Features

Ebb Phase (Option A)

First 24–48 hours
  • ↓ Metabolic rate,
  • ↓ Energy expenditure,
  • ↓ Nitrogen excretion, Hemodynamic stability

Flow Phase or Catabolic phase

2–7 days post-trauma
  • ↑ Metabolic rate,
  • ↑ Oxygen consumption, Catabolism,
  • ↑ Catecholamines

Anabolic Phase (Option C)

Weeks post-trauma
  • Positive nitrogen balance,
  • Protein synthesis,
  • Restoration of tissue mass
